Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Earthquake Catalog and Waveform Analysis to Assess the Evolution of Axial Seamount Surrounding the 2015 Eruption
Award.AbstractNarration:
Axial seamount is an active submarine volcano located off the west coast of the US on the Juan de Fuca midocean ridge spreading center. Axial has recently been instrumented for continuous real-time data monitoring as part of the cabled ocean observatory network of the NSF-sponsored Ocean Observatory Initiative (OOI) that includes high-quality ocean bottom seismic data, as well as an unrivaled set of seafloor geodetic and hydrothermal measurements. The seamount has erupted periodically in the past but the most recent eruption in April/May 2015 was captured by the local seismic network and provides a unique dataset with which to investigate the eruption and magmatic mechanisms associated with submarine volcanoes. The project will analyze the evolution of earthquake properties and statistical patterns in space and time, as well as how these changes are correlated with deformation and hydrothermal outputs throughout the eruption cycle. These data will be used to track changes in stress and the movement of magma within the volcanic edifice, leading to a better understanding of the mechanics of submarine volcanoes and the dynamics of eruptions on the seafloor. This project takes advantage of the recently enabled OOI Axial seamount cabled array data portal and will contribute to scientific infrastructure for undersea monitoring. The project provides research experience for community college students, undergraduates and graduate students, and training for middle-school science teachers in the areas of earthquake physics and submarine volcanic processes.

This project will utilize the compiled Axial Seamount seismic catalog and carry out waveform analysis to assess the evolution of the volcanic system before, during and after the April and May 2015 eruption including the many linkages between earthquakes, seafloor deformation and hydrothermal activity. Stress states will be inferred by monitoring changes in seismicity rate and variations in earthquake statistical patterns. The strength of the faults and/or the movement of fluids will be constrained through earthquake source parameter studies. This project will advance three technical goals: 1) Study the evolution of stress within the volcanic crust through the 2015 eruption at Axial Seamount using a novel combination of techniques, including seismicity/stressing rate changes, earthquake stress drop measurements and seismic b-value studies. 2) Investigate the response of fault systems within the caldera to dynamic stresses in the context of their local stressing history, and by incorporating hydrothermal time series observations that provide new constraints on the role of fluids in dynamic triggering. 3) Explore the exceptional record of explosive acoustic events associated with the 2015 eruption. Although there is increasing evidence that explosive volcanism is common in the deep-sea, there are few direct observations. Understanding the distribution and scaling of these signals may transform our views on eruption dynamics in mid-ocean ridge environments.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During large-scale volcanic eruptions, as magma is withdrawn from a chamber at depth, faults may form in response to the subsidence and collapse of the overlying material.  These collapse structures often exhibit a circular to elliptical pattern in plan view and are commonly referred to as ring faults. Reactivation of ring faults during subsequent smaller scale eruptions has been documented previously; however, the mechanical significance of these structures during different phases of the volcanic cycle remains poorly understood.

 

Axial Seamount is a basaltic shield volcano located at the intersection of the Cobb-Eickelberg hotspot and Juan de Fuca Ridge (offshore Oregon, USA; intermediate spreading rate of 55-60 mm/yr). The summit hosts a caldera at 1500 m below sea level that is an elongate depression, ~3 km wide and 8.5 km long, with walls up to ~150 m high that are buried by lavas on its southern margin. Small-scale submarine eruption have been documented at Axial Seamount in 1998, 2011 and 2015. The most recent eruption during April and May of 2015 was recorded by a network of ocean-bottom seismometers, hydrophones and bottom-pressure sensors that were installed within the caldera as part of the Ocean Observatories Initiative (OOI) Cable Array.  

 

Using data from the OOI Cabled Array, one objective of this project was to examine the movement and strength of Axial Seamount's ring fault complex before, during and after this small volume eruption in April and May of 2015. This research has shown that the movement of the ring system can be tracked very precisely using microearthquake focal mechanism analysis and that strength and seismic coupling of the fault systems varies throughout the inflation-deflation cycle. Prior to the eruption, focal mechanisms showed a pattern of normal slip on outward dipping ring faults consistent with the differential vertical uplift of the caldera floor relative to the rim. During the eruption, seismic activity remained localized along these same fault structures; however, the slip direction was reversed as the caldera floor subsided. After the eruption, as the volcano initally reinflated and the caldera floor uplifted, these faults exhibited sparser seismicity with a more heterogeneous pattern of slip. As our ability to calculate focal mechanisms for microearthquakes in near real-time increases, this analysis may provide a new tool in volcanic monitoring and yield a potentially important short-term indicator of an impending eruption.  The collaborative work carried out as part of this project also has demonstrated the need to incorporate fault slip estimates into the types of geodetic source models that are used to track volcanic inflation and deflation.  These findings may ultimately lead to an improved ability to track the hazards associated with active volcanoes worldwide.

 

The dynamics of lava emplacement in the deep ocean are difficult to study due to challenges associated with making direct visual observations in these extreme environments. The 2015 eruption of Axial Seamount was accompanied by a suite of impulsive hydroacoustic signals recorded by the OOI network.  These sounds were sourced from flows within the caldera, as well as along the Volcano's north rift zone.  They are thought to be associated with explosive or implosive events caused by lava-water interactions.

 

A second objective of this research was to use these water-borne acoustic signals to better constrain the timing and dynamics of volcanic activity. Efforts to detect and locate these signals showed that the eruption began soon after the onset of the seismic crisis and on April 24th and continued until May 20th when the subsidence of the caldera floor (as monitored using bottom pressure) was arrested.  This work also has detailed the position of eruptive centers above the dike as a function of time, with the initial outpouring of lava focused inside the caldera and then extending down rift, with a small regression back toward the volcano over time.  Areas of high explosion density were correlated with newly formed lava mounds along the rift zone and were used to place new constraints on effusion rates and the conditions under which different lava morphologies might form.  

 

The project contributed to geoscience workforce development by supporting two MS students--one of these students went on to work for a company specializing in geohazards and risk assessment, and the other student is now employed as a research technician at a National Laboratory, where he is involved in geothermal energy research.  Two undergraduate students also were involved in this research--one of which is now employed in the geotechnical engineering field and the other is completing a Ph.D. in seismology at another institution.

 

Research supported by this project has contributed to two publicly accessible MS theses and four published peer-reviewed journal articles, with two additional research papers submitted and another near submission.  The project's results were disseminated in more than a dozen presentations at national and international conferences, as well four public colloquiums at academic institutions.
